title: Are hold over damages and court costs in a judgement be discharged. Do property damages are dischargeable?
question: Have a judgement that includes past due rent, hold over damages, and court costs. Also separate property damages that were in excess over the security deposit that tenant did not include in the bankruptcy debts list. .
answers: All of these debts you mention are dischargeable in a bankruptcy. You should meet with a bankruptcy attorney to determine which chapter is best for you. Ideally you qualify for a chapter 7 and that way you can wipe everything out without have to pay any of your creditors.
This appears to be a duplicate post. My answer is the same as I said the first time.
Everything you described is dischargeable. I urge you to meet with a bankruptcy attorney to confirm that bankruptcy is the best option for you.

In CA, all dischargeable debts will be discharged in a no-asset Ch7 ... whether they were listed or not.
Your only option would be to file an Adversary Proceeding to object to the dischargeability of the debt based on, say, malicious intent to cause the property damage. You'll need an attorney to handle this.
